data.title: node-debug: use square brackets in array preview

data.title: [Node 2] Previews for objects and arrays are not shown in Debug console
data.body:
Testing #14340
- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: Mac OS

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have a simple object say

```
myObject = {
a: 1
b: 2
c: 3
d: 4
}
```
1. Look for this object in debug console

Current Debug shows the preview

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10746682/19681757/fa81beba-9aaa-11e6-826d-38cb16068f6c.png)

Debug 2 shows all the properties

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10746682/19681770/0b66248c-9aab-11e6-84a6-d5b7df002768.png)

data.title: name quick fixes that should run on save
data.body:
testing #14299

Instead (or in addition) I wonder if it would be more useful to name the quick fixes that I want to run on save. This might not be a problem today as only a small subset of problems are auto-fixable but I can see conflicts from warnings that you want to be aware of vs warning you want to auto-magically fix (think of remove unused import).

data.title: node2: error message "Exception evaluating `process.pid`: . Will try again later."
data.body:
Testing #14341:

VSCode Version: 1.7.0
node-debug2: 1.7.0
node: v6.5.0
OS Version: macOS 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. run any node program with node2

Observe: a message "Exception evaluating `process.pid`: . Will try again later." shows up on the debug console.

data.title: Disable all is quite broken if repeated
data.body:
Testing #14288

[The same is true for Enable all]

Execute Disable all three times:

![disable-all](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/19681579/30a5c4f6-9aaa-11e6-8c57-25dfe468e9a7.gif)

data.title: Too many quotes?
data.body: I have this tslint rule active `"quotemark": [ true, "double"]` and I see nice error messages ala `''should be " (quotemark)'`. When I select the light bulb tho the code action is a little confusing because I see 3 single quotes and 2 double quotes

data.title: node2: running mocha tests shows empty lines on debug console
data.body:
Testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14341:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.0
- node-debug2: 1.7.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open vscode-node-debug project
2. run mocha tests with node2

Some mocha test output is followed by an empty lines:

![2016-10-25_11-49-58](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/19681403/8879c23c-9aa9-11e6-832f-dc42dc7bee2b.png)

Whereas running tests with node shows this:

![2016-10-25_11-54-19](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/19681459/c66566e6-9aa9-11e6-8ed3-a53bb526d0b4.png)

data.title: 'tslint failure' is harsh wording
data.body: The tslint extension gives little encouraging code actions ala 'Fix xyz tslint failure'. I think that's a little too harsh and some more positive wording should be used

data.title: R language support
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Recent (1.6)
- OS Version: All

This is more of a request for a feature. I searched lot of places to get the R support in visual studio code but I didn't hit any useful places. Are there any plans in future to support it. Microsoft has it's R-tools. And a visual studio extension specifically for R. If they can help for visual studio code. It will be ultimate IDE.

data.title: code --show-versions is bogus
data.body: Why do we have an extra command argument to show versions of extensions? Imho we should just show the versions when you run `code --list-extensions`.

data.title: Format Selection and Format Document don't do anything for JavaScript
[Request] Move line alt+up/down should autoindent
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

I think it would be nice if the moveline feature manage the indentation. For example:

```
hello = "hello"
for i in range(1,10):
    pass                    
```

Move `hello` variable down (current behaviour):

```
for i in range(1,10):
hello = "hello"
    pass
```

Expected behaviour:

```
for i in range(1,10):
    hello = "hello"
    pass
```

data.title: Improve fix on save setting doc
data.body:
testing #14299

The doc for the _fix on save_ setting reads 'Turns auto fix on save on or off' which doesn't mention that the feature isn't available with _auto save after delay_.

data.title: 'defaultSideBySideLayout' naming
data.body:
Refs: #14016

'defaultSideBySideLayout' should be 'defaultEditorGroupLayout'

Especially if you already expose 'editor group layout' everywhere in the UI.

I understand that editor group is nowhere used in settings and that we already have 'sideBySide'. However I do not think that is a good enough reason to go with 'sideBySide'.

data.title: Extension: Reload button jumps from index 1 to 2 in this case
data.body:
Testing #14288
- have a disabled extension that also shows an update
- 
  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/19680979/faa2a0b0-9aa7-11e6-98ba-48a12a25bcd1.png)

=> the reload button is now moved to the right

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/19680991/0589500a-9aa8-11e6-8f8b-27456ad5464b.png)

data.title: Help extension authors through TypeScript 2.0 adoption in `compile` script
data.body:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/19680931/c6705bfc-9aa7-11e6-8736-5b6b7625ea2f.png)

Maybe the `compile` script should still exist and simply tell the user to read the following link:

http://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_6#_extension-authoring

data.title: UX of extensions menu
data.body:
Testing #14288

IMHO this menu has turned into a monster and as a user I cannot work with it anymore. There are all the concepts cramped into a single menu.

IMHO working with extensions involves two operating modes (similar how developing (editing files) and SCM (git) are different operating modes)
1. Finding & installing extensions
2. Managing installed extensions

IMHO these two are distinct activities and they should be treated distinctly in designing the experience.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/19680686/062178ea-9aa7-11e6-89dd-7b2305963ee7.png)

data.title: Middle vs Center labels
data.body:
Refs: #14016

Notice that in vertical layout we call the second group 'Center' and in horizontal layout we call it 'Middle'.
What is the exact difference between the meaning of these two words? Except the fact that the second one goes well with 'Earth'

I suggest to just use the same label in both cases, and since we originally used 'Center' I would go for that one.

data.title: Too many editor group layout actions
data.body:
Refs #14016
1. Command pallete > editor layout
2. Notice there are 3 actions for this simple thing!

I understand that you did that because of some limitations we have with updating the label of an action. But I do not think that is enough motivation to have 3 actions when I only see a use scenario with the toggle action.

My suggestions is just to have a single action with the following name:
'Toggle Editor Vertical/Horizontal Layout'
That title I would also use in the view menu

![screen shot 2016-10-25 at 11 26 49](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/19680547/69c4472a-9aa6-11e6-8de3-5b6002529321.png)

data.title: Extensions: Disable All (workspace) followed by Disable All behaves weird
data.body:
Testing #14288
- disable all (workspace)
- then click on disable all

=> the reload button is removed and the action does not seem to have any impact

data.title: Extension: disablement state not cleared when uninstalling and reinstalling
data.body:
Testing #14288
- have an extension installed
- disable it
- restart with --disable-extensions
- uninstall the extension
- install it again
- restart normally

=> the extension shows up disabled

data.title: UX of Disable and Uninstall feels weird to me
data.body:
Testing #14288
- Disable looks like a button (which makes me think it should be single-clickable) but then it pops up a menu.
- I would personally have a wrench icon or a "Manage" link and put the three actions in there:
  - Disable for current workspace
  - Disable
  - Uninstall

Suggested menu:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/19680555/77d23b06-9aa6-11e6-9697-c16fad92100f.png)
- Also I believe the Reload button should not be a button, but a fly-out at the top of the viewlet that pushes everything down and reads "Some changes will not be applied until you restart" or something like that.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/19680245/451f8336-9aa5-11e6-9c63-d367d7a8db76.png)

data.title: Compile errors when setting engines.vscode to *
data.body:
Testing #14290
- open your extensions `package.json` file
- change the `engine.vscode` property to `*`
- run `npm run postinstall` (assuming you have the `vscode` module as dev-dependency)

Import references to `'vscode'` will have errors:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/19680182/0002f49a-9aa5-11e6-8cd2-6b0e6320f2c7.png)

data.title: Flaky test: WorkspaceConfigurationEditingService - Node write one setting - empty file
data.body: https://travis-ci.org/Microsoft/vscode/jobs/170392419#L7306

data.title: Extensions: Show more info on Reload button
data.body:
Testing #14288

After I click on the reload button you show me exactly what reload will do (e.g. enable an extension). I suggest to show this exact help text as tooltip on the reload button.

data.title: [scss] "semi-colon expected" error for pattern of "url(foo())"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Mac OS X El Capitan 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

Write sass code as below

``` sass
body {
    background: url(foo());
}
```

![qq20161025-1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/930535/19679911/4a7c4d7e-9ad6-11e6-8b25-70a1ce231802.png)

~~Workaround (doesn't work, ignore this workaround): add a space after "url", however, that prevents "url" to be recognized as a keyword.~~
![qq20161025-2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/930535/19679910/4a766ddc-9ad6-11e6-94b7-d8e8a79f859d.png)
**Edit: the workaround above doesn't work, the generated css is not valid.**

Real-life scenario:
`background: url(get-resource-path('images/foo.png', $pool: 'shared'));`
from http://docs.sencha.com/cmd/guides/resource_management.html

data.title: Terminal scrollbar width is 4px thinner than editor's scrollbar
data.body:
Testing #13440

Terminal scrollbar is 4px thinner than editor scrollbar. IMHO it would be more pleasent if their widths would match.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/19679960/28fb56a4-9aa4-11e6-8296-88c22a11b637.png)

data.title: Do not show dropdown for disabled extension if there is only one choice enabled
data.body:
Testing #14288 

Imho when the user can only make one choice, just run this action and do not show me the dropdown. This allows to speed up toggling enablement for many extensions  

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/19679966/2a30d7ec-9aa4-11e6-9a5a-f101867b4136.png)

data.title: Extensions: disablement state needs to be communicated across windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Testing #14288
- open one window and disable an extension for the workspace
- open another window and disable the same extension always

=> the first window still thinks the disabled state is only for the workspace when it was globally disabled
